title: Newcrest pushes ahead with $685m gold mine expansion
text:
Newcrest Mining has pulled the trigger on a $685 million expansion of Australia’s most lucrative gold mine despite concerns about water supply, a tailings dam problem and an increase in seismic events that have taken some of the shine off its Cadia operations.

The expansion includes adding a new block cave to the underground mining operations at Cadia in western NSW and increasing the nameplate capacity of the processing plant to 33 million tonnes a year.

Newcrest continues to study the feasibility of a stage two expansion estimated to cost an additional $180 million.

The company said it would apply for approvals to expand mining and processing once it finalised plans to repair Cadia’s northern tailing dam, a key step in any move by the NSW government to lift a prohibition order imposed after a partial wall failure at the tailings dam in March 2018.

Newcrest chief executive officer Sandeep Biswas said the updated expansion plans for Cadia included higher gold and copper recovery rates than outlined in a 2018 pre-feasibility study.

Mr Biswas said the revised plans were set to deliver an additional 1.8 million ounces of gold and 67,000 tonnes of copper and boost free cash flow by $800 million over the life of the mine.
description: Australia's biggest gold miner confident Cadia can deliver despite recent issues and increase in seismic events.
